importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The event described in the article took place on Tuesday, October 21, 2025, marking the third week of the government shutdown, highlighting the growing impact of the crisis on federal workers.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The shutdown has persisted for over three weeks, during which approximately 1.4 million federal employees have been furloughed or working without pay, leading to severe financial hardship and widespread public concern.

keyTakeAways: A federal shutdown has led to financial hardship for over 1.4 million federal workers, including contractors and employees in agencies like the Department of Commerce and Social Security Administration.
Federal workers such as Summer Kerksick and Rolanda Williams are waiting in long lines at food banks to receive emergency food assistance due to unpaid wages and delayed paychecks.
The Capital Area Food Bank, in partnership with No Limits Outreach Ministries, served over 370 households—more than double the expected number—highlighting the scale of the crisis.
GOP Sen. Ron Johnson proposed a bill that would only pay federal workers who are required to work during the shutdown, while Democrats advocate for universal payment to all federal employees.

Pamelia Carter, a federal worker in the Department of Agriculture with 38 years of service, observes the current crisis as unprecedented and emotionally impactful, noting that the event is unlike regular food outreach programs.
The incident underscores a breakdown in public trust in government employment security, as workers like Williams previously believed federal jobs provided financial stability.

namedEntities.name: Summer Kerksick
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal contractor and market research analyst with the Rural Export Center, U.S. Department of Commerce
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is a representative federal worker experiencing financial hardship due to the shutdown, illustrating the real-life impact of unpaid wages on individual families.

namedEntities.name: Rolanda Williams
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Employee at the Social Security Administration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She exemplifies the shift in perception among federal workers who once believed government jobs were secure, now facing food insecurity due to unpaid wages.

namedEntities.name: Pamelia Carter
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Executive director of No Limits Outreach Ministries and a former federal worker at the Department of Agriculture with 38 years of service
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She provides firsthand experience of past shutdowns and observes the current crisis as unprecedented, emphasizing the scale and emotional toll on federal workers.

namedEntities.name: Ron Johnson
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He introduced a bill proposing to pay only federal workers who are required to continue working during the shutdown, reflecting a partisan divide on how to address worker compensation.

namedEntities.name: Capital Area Food Bank
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It organized a large-scale food distribution event for federal workers during the shutdown, serving over 370 households, demonstrating the public response to worker hardship.

namedEntities.name: No Limits Outreach Ministries
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Local religious organization in Landover, Maryland
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It partnered with the Capital Area Food Bank to host a food pantry event, showing community and faith-based efforts to support federal workers in crisis.

namedEntities.name: Rural Export Center
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Division within the U.S. Department of Commerce
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It employs Summer Kerksick, illustrating the breadth of federal workforce affected by the shutdown across various agencies.

namedEntities.name: Social Security Administration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It employs Rolanda Williams, demonstrating how even core federal agencies are impacted by the shutdown and resulting financial instability.

namedEntities.name: Department of Agriculture
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is where Pamelia Carter has spent 38 years working, showing long-term federal employment exposure and its disruption during the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: U.S. Department of Commerce
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is where Summer Kerksick works, highlighting how shutdowns affect workers across multiple federal departments.

summaryOfNewsArticle: As the federal government shutdown enters its third week, over 1.4 million federal workers—including contractors and employees from agencies like the Department of Commerce and Social Security Administration—are facing financial distress due to unpaid wages. In response, a food bank event in Landover, Maryland, organized by the Capital Area Food Bank and No Limits Outreach Ministries, served over 370 households—far exceeding expectations—demonstrating widespread need. Federal workers like Summer Kerksick and Rolanda Williams describe the sudden loss of income and the emotional shock of needing food assistance, challenging the belief that federal employment guarantees financial stability. Senator Ron Johnson has introduced a bill to pay only those who work during the shutdown, while Democrats advocate for universal payment. The event underscores both the human cost of political gridlock and the growing public demand for accountability in government operations.
title: Federal workers form line down the block for food pantry as shutdown hits third-week mark
